title: 103_s2314
content: The "Court of Federal Claims Administration Act of 1994" allows judges to continue in office until a successor is appointed, grants authority to conduct proceedings in territorial courts, and addresses the residence of retired judges. The Court of Federal Claims Administration Act of 1994 addresses the residence of retired judges, stating that retired judges of the Court of Federal Claims are not restricted as to residence and their official duty station is where they live. SEC. 5 amends Section 331 of title 28, United States Code, to include the chief judge of the United States Court of Federal Claims in the Judicial Conference participation. SEC. 6 establishes the Court of Federal Claims Judicial Conference. SEC. 6 adds a new section to Chapter 15 of title 28, allowing the chief judge of the Court of Federal Claims to convene an annual judicial conference for court business and justice administration improvements. The Court of Federal Claims must ensure bar representation and participation. SEC. 7 amends Section 797(a) of title 28, allowing judges of the Court of Federal Claims on disability status to be designated as senior judges and recalled for judicial service. Section 1491(a) of title 28, United States Code is amended to grant the Court of Federal Claims jurisdiction for monetary relief and to render judgment on contractor disputes under section 10(a)(1). The Court of Federal Claims has jurisdiction over contractor disputes under section 10(a)(1) of the Contract Disputes Act of 1978, including termination of contracts, property rights, cost accounting standards, and nonmonetary disputes. Additionally, the court has ancillary jurisdiction to render judgment on related tort claims authorized by section 2674 of the title. In cases within the jurisdiction of the Court of Federal Claims for judicial review of agency action, section 706 of title 5 applies. Section 178 of title 28, United States Code, is amended to allow Court of Federal Claims judges on senior status after age 65 to receive annuities deemed as payment for services under specific provisions. Section 179 of title 28, United States Code, designates Court of Federal Claims judges as officers of the United States for the purpose of applying certain provisions of title 5. Court of Federal Claims judges are designated as officers of the United States under Section 179 of title 28, United States Code. This Act and its amendments will take effect on the date of enactment.
